awd_titl_txt: High Capacity MM-Wave Wireless Communication Systems Using Spatially Adaptive Smart Antenna Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past two decades, wireless technologies operating at traditional frequency bands (<6GHz) evolved into data intensive communication systems by enjoying innovations such as cognitive radio, multiple antenna systems, heterogeneous networks, and machine-to-machine communications. These innovations are currently not satisfactory to address the significantly enhanced data rate needs for future generations (5G and beyond) of wireless communication systems. Consequently, wider frequency bandwidths available at mm-Wave bands (above 10GHz) have recently attracted a strong interest from the wireless community to be able to serve the future data rate demands. Therefore, in this project, the aim is to enhance the capacity and the data rate of wireless communication systems based on the wireless channel control phenomenon by investigating the use of spatial (i.e. position) adaptation of smart antenna arrays. At mm-Wave bands, position adaptations on the order of a few centimeters can practically be realized within compact devices and yet provide new wireless channel opportunities and interference mitigation. The preliminary studies demonstrate that wireless channel opportunities achieved through such spatial adaptations can improve the wireless system capacity beyond a factor of 2.5 to 5. Hence, the results of this project are expected to be transformative in adaptive wireless communications area and the resulting knowledge base is expected to have effects on commercial, emergency, and military communication domains. Immediate tangible outcome of this project will be a system level test bed that will provide results, outcomes, and design guidelines to prospective designers within academia and industry. The proposed activity will also lead to improve the curriculums through developing lab experiments and test beds. Efforts will be made to incite the participation of the minority students via seminars, technology fairs, and specialized events. Broad dissemination is ensured via conference and journal publications, workshops, and tutorials. Specialized outreach sessions will be organized at local high schools and community colleges to expose and attract students, particularly minorities to STEM disciplines.

This proposal introduces a novel wireless system adaptation strategy based on repositioning of mm-Wave antenna arrays during the system operation to control the wireless channel gain. The recent developments in the areas of microfluidic based reconfigurable RF devices and multi-dimensional (i.e. frequency, time, and spatial domains) dynamic spectrum access techniques are jointly investigated, for the first time, to significantly enhance wireless communication system performance. Beam and position adaptable antennas at the transmitter and receiver are used to control the multipath channel characteristics so that a favorable effective channel response for the communication link can be obtained.  Unlike the on-going research efforts that focus on mm-Wave wireless systems harnessing beam-steering capability, the proposed system envisions a paradigm shift in the physical layer by controlling the wireless channel using a combination of the beam-steering and position adapting functionalities. Position adaptation is planned to be carried out in a compact, efficient, and high precision device by introducing microfluidically reconfigurable feed networks. The proposed unusual combination of beam-steering and position reconfiguration generates a need for this proposed effort to investigate and revise the long-time established channel estimation, tracking, prediction, and compensation techniques. The proposed main research thrusts are (1) Controlling mm-Wave Wireless Channel; (2) System Design in Heterogeneous Networks; (3) Spatially Adaptive Smart mm-Wave Antenna Arrays; (4) Verification of Theory Predicted Channel Capacity Enhancement with mm-Wave Wireless Communication Scenarios.

por.por_cntn:
Wireless channel had been conventionally accepted to be an uncontrollable phenomenon since the physical environment and the propagation scenario that determine fading channel gain are assumed to be beyond the control of the communication nodes. This perception leads to transceivers to be developed based on statistical models of the wireless channel. The research work carried out under this award introduced a novel wireless system adaptation strategy based on repositioning of mm-Wave antenna arrays during the system operation to control the wireless channel gain. The small wavelengths of the mm-Wave band enable to perform rapid physical movements on the order of few wavelengths within devices and offer this new opportunity for systems. To enhance the data rates beyond the state of the art, the carried out research effort challenged the fundamental perception of the uncontrollable wireless channel with the novel concept of wireless channel control via simultaneous beam-steering and antenna array positioning.  

The wireless channel control and low-cost highly efficient reconfigurable mm-Wave antenna arrays addressed the critical shortage of wireless capacity and increase the ability of wireless systems to better adapt and react to the random channel impairments. The results of the carried out project led to a new direction in cognitive and adaptive radio field. This new direction and the developed knowledge base have had effects on various communication domains. The developed antenna and wireless communication system concepts also provided novel solutions for lowering the power requirements of the communication and be applicable for unmanned vehicles that are intended to be operated in critical scenarios for the society.  Our original approach also recently expanded to large intelligent surfaces and attracted so much interest among the wireless community.  A novel concept of shaping electromagnetic energy in the spatial domain using channel control   mechanisms such as repositionable dynamic RISs and multiple coordinated ambiant backscatterers which is analogous to pulse shaping in time and frequency domain is introduced. Investigating the advantage of multiple static remote intelligent surfaces (RIS), the coverage area of secondary users is increased. Then, we've added a novel property to RIS concept, which called repositionable dynamic RIS, providing more robustness to shadowing and power fluctuations in short time frame.  Our approach has also lead new directions on interference management and resource allocation techniques utilizing channel control. In a further study, a paradigm-shift on non-orthogonal multiple access towards the application-centric waveform coexistence is introduced. Our work enables coexistence of different waveforms corresponding different wireless technologies on the same time-frequency resources. The approach later is also extended to the co-existence in the same geographical region.

The project introduced first prototypes of mm-wave antenna arrays capable of changing their own physical locations to maximize the wireless channel gain. Specifically, position adaptation capability was provided by utilizing microfluidics based reconfiguration where antenna array was realized on a selectively metallized plate (SMP) that is placed/repositioned within a high aspect ratio microfluidic channel. New fabrication approaches were introduced to realize walls of the microfluidic channels from hard materials to enable reliable high aspect microfluidic channel ratios to host the SMP of the antenna array. The compactness of the position adapting antenna array was achieved by a novel feed technique that utilized the bottom surface of the SMP for feed coupling/matching while using the top surface of the SMP for the antenna array. High radiation efficiency and actuation speed were achieved that can lead to increase in the wireless system level average spectral efficiency by 100%.  

The outcomes of the proposed research have laid the foundations of a new, considerably more efficient system of wireless communication systems. Thus, it can increase spectral efficiency and battery usage efficiency. This will lead to reduced end user prices and longer battery life and communication performance in wireless communication systems. As a consequence, consumers directly benefit from these advances by receiving better wireless service at reduced costs; network operators obtain higher return on investment for their very expensive spectrum holdings, and the wireless device and network equipment manufacturers can have new products in their lineup.
